text:
LIVE: Hundreds evacuated as Port Hills burn - Yahoo New Zealand Follow the latest developments on the Port Hills fire here. Close Stunning images emerge of Port Hills fire UP NEXT VIDEO Photographer Oliver Watson has shared stunning images taken from behind the cordons overnight. Source: Oliver Watson, Facebook. Stunning images emerge of Port Hills fire 
AT A GLANCE: - Eleven houses and two sheds have been destroyed.- More than 130 firefighters are currently on the ground fighting the Port Hills fire.- A state of emergency has been declared in Christchurch and Selwyn.- Around 450 houses have been evacuated.- The blazes have burned through 1850 hectares of land.- One person has been killed fighting the fires - chopper pilot and ex-SAS solider Steve Askin.- Dozens of homes are without power. 
KEY INFORMATION FOR RESIDENTS: - A number of evacuation centres have been set up at Halswell Library, Selwyn Events Centre in Lincoln, Te Hapua Halswell Centre on Halswell Rd, Nga Hau e Wha Marae on Pages Rd.- A Facebook page has been set up for fire evacuees. Find it here. - People are being advised to stay away from the hills to allow emergency services access and ensure swift evacuation.- If you are at all worried or uncomfortable remaining in your home, please evacuate. You can go to either of the city welfare centres for assistance.- Orion remain on full alert, ready to respond to any issues with power supply as a result of the fires. It is possible that there will be further outages until the fire is fully extinguished. 
LATEST: 
10.05pm: 
Here's a brilliant timelapse, shared on social media, of the smoke rising from Port Hills earlier in the day: — Josh Gallagher (@joshgallagher76) February 16, 2017 
9.32pm: — william rae (@macrae85) February 16, 2017 
Meanwhile, a message posted to Facebook by the Governors Bay Volunteer Fire Brigade has doused positive reflections on the effort to contain the fire so far. 
"After a long day of hard slog on the hills digging up hot spots and dealing with flare ups we are happy to say the majority of the fire has been contained. Photo: Governors Bay Volunteer Fire Brigade/Facebook 
"Mother nature will have a large effect on what happens over the next few days, we can only hope she gives us a well deserved break. 
"We appreciate the community support, especially with the food effort, however the crews have been stood down from the continuous watch that started Monday and will now respond as required, however we do not require any more food donations at this stage. We would like to thank the community for the support once more." 
8.55pm: — Eugenie Sage (@EugenieSage) February 16, 2017 Cloud is increasing along the Port Hills in #christchurch . Drizzle is likely by morning and heaviest rain by Saturday morning #porthillsfire 
8.18pm: 
The Christchurch City Council has released its evening summary of Thursday's events in the Port Hills. 
Offers of assistance have been received from the United States and Australia to support the Port Hills fire response. 
The Port Hills blaze has claimed 11 houses and two sheds, according to latest reports. Photo: Getty 
Four of the houses are in Worsleys Road, four in Hoon Hay Valley Road, one house and one shed on Burkes Bush Road, and two houses and one shed on Early Valley Road. 
Civil Defence is receiving inquiries from residents who have been evacuated about when they will be able to return to their homes. 
People are encouraged to monitor Civil Defence and Council web and social media channels for the latest updates. As soon as any information is available about when people can return, Civil Defence will ensure that it is widely publicised. Photo: Getty 
Christchurch Civil Defence controller Dave Adamson has welcomed offers of assistance from the United States and Australia to support the Port Hills fire response. 
The latest offers of assistance/response: 
– United States Coast Guard heavy icebreaker USCGC Polar Star offers to help– Hercules heads to Australia to collect fire retardant– 14 helicopters and 3 fixed wing aircraft were used today– Special fire pods are being used to shoot high-pressure water into the ground to extinguish roots burning below the surface– Almost 400 people have been on the ground fighting the blaze– Efforts are focused on controlling the fire – it is not possible to assess the status of individual properties at this stage– Cordons remain in place with police and Defence Force staff patrolling 
A state of emergency was declared on Wednesday evening and Prime Minister Bill English visited the scene on Thursday. 
The fire, which started in Marleys Hills on Monday night, has now spread over 1800 hectares on the Port Hills. 
– Read the council's full update here . 
7.59pm: — Geri Kerr (@GSK43) February 16, 2017 
7.08pm: 
Eleven homes have been destroyed as winds fan the fire raging in Christchurch's Port Hills. 
Fire Service Assistant Area Commander Greg Crawford told NZME that firefighters were on top of the situation at present. 
However, conditions could change in an instance. Photo: Getty 
"With the air attack assisting, we’ve got got about 10 pieces of heavy machinery cutting fire breaks, we’re really aggressively pushing the fire breaks towards the fire in the hopes that we can stop it before it does any more damage," he said. 
"We are very dependent on the air operation and wind change." 
6.42pm: 
The Christchurch Transport Operations' Centre says there are currently no changes to the existing road closures in place due to the Port Hills fires. 
Unless there is a significant change the next update will be made by 7am on Friday. Road closure information: 
– Cashmere Rd is closed between Hendersons Rd and Kaiwara St– Penruddock Rise is also closed at Cashmere Rd– Worsleys Rd is closed at Cashmere Rd– Hoon Hay Valley Rd is closed at Cashmere Rd– Kennedys Bush Rd is closed at Cashmere Rd – Sutherland Road is closed at Cashmere Rd– Worsleys Track from Worlseys Rd is closed– Dyers Pass Road is closed between Hackthorne Road to Governors Bay Rd. Use the Lyttelton Tunnel or Gebbies Pass as the alternate route– Summit Road is closed between Gebbies Pass and Rapaki Track– Old Tai Tapu Road is closed between Osterholts Road and Early Valley Rd– Early Valley Road is closed at Old Tai Tapu Rd No change to the Port Hills Fire road closures here's your 6pm update: https://t.co/g5wn4sloE0 ^TF — NZTA Canterbury/WC (@NZTACWC) February 16, 2017 
6.26pm: 
Civil Defence has recommended no recreational activities, including camping, cycling and picnics, within a 'yellow line boundary' until further notice. Civil Defence's 'yellow line' boundary. Photo: Civil Defence 
The boundary, which was modeled on the current fire situation and weather forecasts, shows where further fire spread and smoke could pose a risk and cause health concerns. 
"It is important for non-residents to stay away from the marked area to allow access for emergency services who are working in this area," Christchurch Civil Defence Emergency Management said. 
5.56pm: 
The MetService says patches of drizzle will develop in Christchurch on Friday afternoon, but unfortunately it won't be enough to put out the fire in the Port Hills. Patchy drizzle developing late Friday till Sunday. Not enough rain water to put out the #porthillsfire . Lucky we have @NZfireservice . ^Lisa pic.twitter.com/uF127hYojj — MetService (@MetService) February 16, 2017 
5.48pm: 
The New Zealand Defence Force will pick up about 15 tonnes of fire retardant materials from Australia and send another fire pod to help battle the fast-spreading blaze on Christchurch’s Port Hills. 
Air Commodore Kevin McEvoy, the Acting Commander Joint Forces New Zealand, said an Air Force C-130 Hercules aircraft is on its way to Australia to pick up five pallets of firefighting foam and other fire-retardant materials. 
A detachable fire pod is also being shipped from Wellington by ferry this evening, in addition to the four NZDF fire pods currently being used to fight the Christchurch fires. The pods can be transported on a variety of vehicles and use an ultra high-pressure hose with a pointed nozzle that can pierce the ground and douse burning roots. Our C130 Hercules just about to take off to Melbourne, to get more fire fighting supplies for #PortHillsFire pic.twitter.com/4nloKuPfcK — LTGEN Tim Keating (@CDF_NZ) February 16, 2017 
An additional fire response team made up of four experienced firefighters has been sent to join the six Army firefighters currently working with Selwyn fire authorities. 
"Our Defence Force is committed to supporting the local community in any way we can. We remain ready to provide additional assistance if required," Air Commodore McEvoy said. A Royal New Zealand Air Force C-130 Hercules left the Whenuapai Base in Auckland on Thursday afternoon. Photo: NZDF 
He said the United States Coast Guard heavy icebreaker USCGC Polar Star, currently visiting Lyttelton, is willing to assist the Government’s emergency response. 
"The NZDF is currently liaising with the ship’s captain to discuss how we can integrate the ship’s personnel into our relief operations in Christchurch." 
5.14pm: 
The wreckage of a helicopter that crashed on Wednesday, killing decorated ex-SAS soldier David "Steve" Askin, has been recovered. 
The Transport Accident Investigation Commission released a statement about its recovery on Thursday afternoon. 
"The wreckage was in a steep gully under the Sugarloaf and conditions were hot and windy, making it challenging for the ground crew loading the wreckage, and the investigators," Transport Accident Investigation Commission investigator Steve Walker said. The helicopter's fuselage is lifted from a steep gully. Photo: Transport Accident Investigation Commission 
The wreckage was lifted out in five loads and placed on a truck for transport to a secure site in Christchurch from where it will be transported to the Commission’s technical facility in Wellington for further analysis. 
The Commission had planned to begin the air lift this morning but had to wait for clearance to use the road which had been closed because of the threat from the bush fire. RIP Steve. A brave soldier & a recipient of the NZ Gallantry Star, he served NZ with courage and commitment. pic.twitter.com/XIKUGFrO0t — LTGEN Tim Keating (@CDF_NZ) February 15, 2017 
Meanwhile, a support page set up for the deceased pilot's family has raised over $80,000. 
Donations can be made here . 
4.42pm: 
The Christchurch Civil Defence says police cordons in the Port Hills area will remain in place overnight and possibly into the weekend. 
"All current police cordons in the Port Hills area for the fire emergency will remain in place for the night of the 16 February," an update said. 
"It is likely they will stay in place until the Saturday 18 when it will be re-accessed." 
4.35pm: 
Power company Orion has given an update on Christchurch's power supply, stating that around 128 customers still remain without power in the Port Hills. 
Orion says supply has been maintained throughout the rest of the city. 
Lines in the fire affected area in the Port Hills remain off grid, and power continues to be rerouted, including through Orion's new underground, Northern Loop cable. 
Cantabrians are being urged to conserve power where possible to reduce network loads. 
Further outages are possible as the fire continues. 
4.14pm: 
Helicopters fighting the Port Hills blaze have just over four hours of daylight left before they have to stop for the day. 
According to NZME , flare ups occurred soon after pilots finished dousing the fires over the last two nights. There are fears that the fires could flare up again once helicopter pilots stop for the day. Photo: Getty 
Meanwhile, people are still turning up to view the blaze from Bengal Drive. Photo: SNPA 
NZME reports that parents are bringing their children to see the now-famous fire and there is a constant stream of cars driving up. 
Worried home owners are also appearing at Bengal Dr, desperate to get a glimpse of their properties. 3.51pm: 
The US Antarctic research ship Polar Star, docked in Lyttelton, has offered personnel to help in the response to the raging Port Hills fire, parliament has been told. 
"This offer has been formally accepted by the New Zealand government," said Justice Minister Amy Adams. 
"Defence Force personnel are engaging with the Polar Star to determine the best employment of these additional personnel." The US Polar Star. Photo: U.S. Coast Guard 
Ms Adams was briefing parliament on the government's response to the fire. 
She gave an assurance it would provide whatever resources were needed. 
"Civil Defence is working closely with a number of agencies to help support and coordinate the responses and ensure those on the ground receive the help they need," she said. We have sent at least 30 more soldiers and equipment to #PortHillsFire and have additional resources on standby pic.twitter.com/ZcBWmUvY8a — LTGEN Tim Keating (@CDF_NZ) February 15, 2017 
"Local police have a dedicated team of around 50 officers on the ground focused on evacuation, managing cordons, and providing reassurance to communities." 
The government assistance includes: 
– 45 Department of Conservation staff– Defence Force liaison officers manning two emergency operation centres– 42 Defence Force staff assisting the police– Defence Force logistics staff and equipment, ready to help evacuations 
She said the Air Force was going to fly in an additional 21 police officers from Auckland to Christchurch on Monday to bolster police numbers. 
3.18pm: 
NIWA has forecast light rain and higher humidity for the Christchurch area on Friday, but the amount of precipitation will be minimal. Light rain + higher humidity headed for #porthillsfire & #Christchurch area on Friday, but amount will be very minimal (less than 3mm). pic.twitter.com/HQAM5RhtXm — Niwa Weather (@NiwaWeather) February 16, 2017 
3.17pm: 
Gerry Brownlee has praised those on the ground for their efforts and the huge amount of "goodwill" that came from them giving up their time and putting their lives on the line. 
His visit came a day after he questioned the emergency response to the blaze, including why a state of emergency wasn't called sooner. Gerry Brownlee and Bill English toured the area being fought by firefighters on Thursday. Photos: Getty 
"I think the most accurate advice I was getting yesterday came from the media," he said on Thursday. 
He didn't lay blame on the rural fire services, firefighters or volunteers who who were in charge of the blaze at the time, rather said it was a legislative issue. 
LATEST: Gerry Brownlee says best advice on Port Hills fires he received 'was from the media' UP NEXT VIDEO Gerry Brownlee says best advice on Port Hills fires he received 'was from the media' Gerry Brownlee says best advice on Port Hills fires he received 'was from the media' "I don't want any suggestion out there from me that they've been doing anything other than an amazing job. These are very brave people doing a great job, there's no question about that," he said.
"It's structures inside the legislative arrangements that fall to politicians to fix and we've got to fix it." 
Labour says Mr Brownlee should have called a state of emergency himself, allowing fire services to commandeer resources as soon as they were needed. 
2.34pm: 
The funeral of the helicopter pilot who died fighting the Port Hills fires will be held on Monday, NZME reports. 
Steve Askin's chopper crashed near Sugarloaf on Tuesday. 
A Givealittle page set up to raise money for his wife and two children, seven and 14, had raised more than $72,000 by Thursday afternoon. 
2.11pm: 
Prime Minister Bill English says there's evidence arson could be to blame for the Port Hills fire. 
He cancelled a series of events across the country on Thursday to travel to Christchurch with Civil Defence Minister Gerry Brownlee. 
"I've only had a very brief description of the fire starting in two places at about the same time which, to someone like me, looks a bit suspicious," Mr English said after viewing the area from a helicopter. 
MORE: 'Contained but not controlled': PM Bill English updates status of Port Hills fire UP NEXT VIDEO 'Contained but not controlled': PM Bill English updates status of Port Hills fire. Source One News 'Contained but not controlled': PM Bill English updates status of Port Hills fire Saw first-hand the tough job facing firefighters in Christchurch. We're committed to providing the resources needed to combat the fire. pic.twitter.com/JhqEI6NzRl — Bill English (@pmbillenglish) February 16, 2017 
"I wouldn't want to jump to conclusions but that seems a bit odd." 
Investigations are still underway to confirm the cause of the blaze. 
2.05pm: Christchurch photographer Brent Smith has captured these incredible images – and many others – of the fires tearing through Port Hills, all of which he has shared via his Facebook page . Photo courtesy: Brent Smith Photo courtesy Brent Smith 
1.43pm: Commonwealth Games mountain bike champion Anton Cooper has two reasons to hope the Port Hills fire doesn't inflict further damage. 
The Christchurch-based rider was one of the thousands forced to evacuate their houses. 
His is situated in the suburb of Westmorland. 
Cooper is also concerned about the future of the newly-built Christchurch Adventure Park. Anton Cooper says his fingers are crossed for the future of the Christchurch Adventure Park. Photo: Getty Images 
The venue features a host of mountainbike trails and was hailed by Cooper upon its completion last year. 
"The fight to save the park and facilities is still ongoing, my fingers are crossed!" Cooper wrote on Facebook. 
The 22-year-old has moved in with his Christchurch parents and will remain based there ahead of next week's national and Oceania championships in Wanaka. 
The former junior world champion managed to salvage his bikes and riding equipment before evacuating on Wednesday night. 
"Feeling big time for all those who have lost their homes and the family of the helicopter pilot (David Steven Askin) who lost his life fighting the blaze," Cooper wrote. Source: Oliver Watson. 
1.21pm: When asked about whether a state of emergency should have been declared earlier, both the PM and Civil Defence Minister Gerry Brownlee said reviews of procedure need to be done after the fires have been dealt with. 
Brownlee said yesterday he had been getting most of his information about the fire from the media. 
"I am not criticising anyone on the ground here, it's structures." 
He said there seemed to be "some gaps between the rural Fire Service and Civil Defence". 
The Civil Defence Minister said the staff from the Fire Service who are tackling the blaze are "very brave". 
1.18pm: Bill English said the Australian fire department had made a "generous and open offer" to send resources. 
He said they may take up the offer if they need to. 
"I will be thanking the prime minster [Malcolm Turnbull]," he said, adding "we appreciate the generosity of Australia". English will be thanking Turnbull for the offer. Source: Getty. 
He said it was a good example of the strong Trans-Tasman relationship. 
1.15pm: Prime Minister Bill English says the process of fighting the fire will take several days. Bill English speaks to media. Source: 1 NEWS. 
He said he did not think the average Kiwi would be questioning how authorities had handled the response. 
"I think the most urgent issue has been the containment of the fire and ensuring that people at risk are dealt with and that appears to have been a very professional and successful effort." 
1.11pm: Bill English says it was "pretty testing circumstances" but firefighters are doing a good job at keeping it contained. 
The Prime Minister said at a media conference today that "the firefighting effort has been focussed" and "professional". 
He said there was no doubt someone would look at the response to the fire in time. 
"People will go back through the process and that's for another day." 
1pm: The Cawthron Eye, a tool that displays NASA satellite images of New Zealand, has captured this image from this morning which displays the scale of the raging fire in the Port Hills. Source: cawthron.org.nz 
You can see it here. 
12.50pm: So that residents can stay in touch with loved ones during the wild fires in Christchurch, we’ve opened up 107 of our Free WiFi hotspots 1/2 — Spark (@SparkNZ) February 15, 2017 
12.42pm: Kiwis moved by the death of a decorated soldier and helicopter pilot while battling fires in Christchurch's Port Hills are donating generously to his family. 
Before 1pm on Thursday morning, more than 1000 donors had gifted $70,126.00 to a Givealittle page set up to help the family of David Steven Askin, known as Steve. 
The 38-year-old died when the Squirrel helicopter he was flying crashed near Sugar Loaf carpark on Tuesday as a dozen choppers were fighting blazes in the area. 
Mr Askin's father Paul Askin on Thursday told 1 News the family was pulling together to support each other over the loss of his popular son."You know I've lost a son but I had him for thirty eight years," he said. 
"His little kids are only four and seven, they've lost a dad, it's a huge hole." Steve Askin was fighting the fires that have torn through Port Hills in Christchurch. Source: Way to Go Heliservices. 
Liam Renshaw was in the army with Mr Askin and said the pair had got up to lots of mischief together. 
"He touched everybody's lives, he was very charismatic," he said. RIP Steve. A brave soldier & a recipient of the NZ Gallantry Star, he served NZ with courage and commitment. pic.twitter.com/XIKUGFrO0t — LTGEN Tim Keating (@CDF_NZ) February 15, 2017 
"He was a very skilled pilot and had a lot of respect in the industry. He will be missed in the aviation community." 
12.24pm: Sport Canterbury says Christchurch City Council has withdrawn the approval for the Mitre 10 MEGA - A Run to Remember to proceed this weekend due to the fires in the Port Hills. 
"There is currently an exclusion zone for the firefighting helicopters along the scheduled route for the run and firefighters are expected to be committed through to at least Saturday at this stage." 
12.21pm: Some of New Zealand's bigger fires: 
March 1918 - The "Raetihi Conflagration" bush fire in the central North Island claimed the lives of three family members and more than 150 buildings plus nine sawmills were destroyed 
February 1946 - A cigarette butt is thought to have started a fire on the Wairakei-Oruanui Road near Taupo. It managed to cross the Waikato River and threaten Taupo itself. It eventually burned through tens of thousands of hectares and forced a law change which allowed adequate provision for rural fire control 
February 1983 - A farm burnoff at Ohinewairua Station, near Waiouru, went out of control and burned through about 15,000ha of tussock and beech forest. 
December 2000 - The Boxing Day Wither Hills fire, near Blenheim, tore through more than 6000ha, damaging 29 properties. It took nearly three months to extinguish 
November 2011 - A helicopter pilot and his passenger were killed when trying to rescue people trapped by a fire at Karikari Beach in Northland. The deliberately lit fire burned through 130ha of scrub 
February 2017 - A fire in Christchurch's Port Hills burns through more than 2000ha, destroying at least 11 houses, and a helicopter pilot helping fight the blaze is killed in a crash. 
12.19pm: The latest update from Christchurch City Council and Civil Defence: 
More than 130 firefighters are currently on the ground fighting the Port Hills fire. 
The main activity is in the northern area of the Port Hills, including Hoon Hay Valley Road, Dyers Pass Road and Worsley Road. 
The Fire Service has 40 crews with 45 pumps and tankers and there are 26 rural fire crews with more than 200 personnel. Fourteen helicopters are in the air, along with three fixed wing aircraft. 
The situation is constantly changing regarding property damage, but the latest report is that 11 houses and two sheds have been lost. Four of the houses are in Worsleys Road, four in Hoon Hay Valley Road, one house and one shed on Burkes Bush Road, and two houses and one shed on Early Valley Road. Fire crews planning their next move. Source: Christchurch City Council. 
Civil Defence is receiving inquiries from residents who have been evacuated about when they will be able to return to their homes. It is too soon to be able to answer this with any certainty. People are encouraged to monitor Civil Defence and Council web and social media channels for the latest updates. As soon as any information is available about when people can return Civil Defence will ensure that it is widely publicised. 
The fire, which started in Marleys Hills on Monday night has now spread over 1800 hectares on the Port Hills. 
Emergency services are preparing to continue their operations for at least over the weekend and say the immediate emphasis is on directing the huge fire away from people and property. 
Helicopters have been brought in from throughout the South Island and out of town fire service staff from both Nelson and Timaru and are boosting local resources. 
There are concerns about the short-term weather forecast with today’s north-east wind today expected to further drive the fronts. It is hoped a south-west change predicted for tomorrow will lower temperatures and humidity, slowing the fire’s progress. The Red Cross has mobilised to help. Source: Christchurch City Council. 
There is a total fire ban in place in North and Canterbury. Fire Region Manager Steve Turek says it is important that there is no type of fire lit so fire resources can remain concentrated on the major fire. 
Christchurch Police have dedicated 50 staff working around the clock on the operation. Police, assisted by New Zealand Defence Force staff, have managed the evacuation of residents in at-risk areas. 400 homes have been evacuated by police with hundreds of other residents choosing to self-evacuate. 
Superintendent John Price of Christchurch Police says patrols are also working around the clock in both areas at risk and those evacuation. “We are providing reassurance to residents about evacuation, but also to others that we are keeping a watchful eye on their property,” he said. 
No evacuations are underway at this time, but police warn the situation is extremely volatile and should the fire change direction, people may have to leave at short notice. 
Police are also checking on the safety of contractors working on the fire, logging everyone who goes into and out of the cordon. 
The main message remains - the police are stressing that it is imperative that members of the public keep away from the hills. People “rubber-necking” are disrupting the emergency response and making it harder for police and fire services to do their jobs. 
The New Zealand Defence Force had 36 staff working alongside emergency services last night and another 25 have joined the operation this morning. 
Welfare and health agencies are on standby to step in at a moment’s notice. Christchurch District Health Board reported no overnight admissions due to respiratory issues. St John had dealt with a number of minor issues. Source: Christchurch City Council. 
Around 11 evacuees are currently at the Te Hapua Halswell Centre. Catering is being provided with donations from the local supermarket assisting. 
While the Welfare Centre has been set up in the community room at Te Hapua Halswell Centre, the facility’s library and pool are operating as usual. 
12.18pm: Civil Defence says 11 homes have been lost as well as two sheds. 
- Four houses on Worsleys Rd- Four houses on Hoon Hay Valley Rd- Two houses and a shed on Early Valley Rd- One house and one shed on Burkes Bush Rd. 
12.05pm: The Port Hills fire in Christchurch has affected some New Zealand Post services in the area. 
The following postal delivery rounds are affected on Thursday 16 February: 
- There will be no deliveries in Westmoreland, Shalamar Drive, Cashmere Road (for street numbers from 150 onwards) including Worsleys Road and the surrounding streets.- There will be no delivery to addresses above Hackthorne Rd.- There will be no delivery to Hyndhope, 124-189 Kennedys Bush, Watlings, The Ridge, Rock Hill Drive, Quarry Hill Tce, The Rocks and Quarryman’s Lane. 
NZ Post said they are continuing to monitor the situation and will provide further updates when information becomes available. 
12pm: — James Shaw (@jamespeshaw) February 15, 2017 
11.42am: Lawyer Tim Fournier is anxiously waiting to hear if his home on Worsleys Rd house is still standing after being evacuated on Wednesday night. 
"I'm trying to get information. In these situations it always seems hard for the people actually affected to get information," he told Fairfax. 
11.19am: Christchurch residents are flooding a Facebook page with offers to host evacuees from the Port Hills fire. 
"2 rooms available in Halswell, as well as a big back yard available for pets," Hannah Jordan posted on Thursday in a message typical of those appearing on the Evacuation housing Facebook page. 
Another Facebook user, Fiona Russell, did not have a spare room to offer but says she can help with babysitting if needed. 
"I work full-time but if you need to have a couple of hours after work to sort out some life admin I'd love to help. I'm experienced with kids," she wrote. Source: Facebook. 
James Frost took to the page asking for help. 
"Hi all, lost my home in the quakes and now lost house in the fire," he said. 
"Feeling really unsettled and would be so happy if anyone had a caravan/campervan with facilities we could use for a while." 
His post had attracted almost 50 comments and offers of help in one hour. 
Christchurch Civil Defence recently tweeted its support for the Facebook page set up on Wednesday by user Robert Norman Read and advised those wishing to help people affected by the fires to also call 03 347 2740. 
10.38am: Deaf Aotearoa have been providing updates here. 
10.23am: More than 100 homes remain without power. Source: Orion. 
10.05am: The emergency Civil Defence bunker at Parliament has been activated as a result of the fire. 
10.03am: People can use evacuation housing FB page to offer support & accommodation: https://t.co/YzTUWvgMhd Call 03 347 2740 with offers of help 
9.53am: Displaced resident Nikki Lynn told Breakfast they were told by police not to get anything out of their home as they needed to leave immediately. 
9.48am: People can use evacuation housing FB page to offer support & accommodation: https://t.co/YzTUWvgMhd Call 03 347 2740 with offers of help — ChristchurchCDEM (@CDEMCHCH) February 15, 2017 
9.38am: SPCA Canterbury says they can provide temporary accommodation for animals evacuated overnight. 
"We are aware that hundreds of people and pets were evacuated overnight. We are working as a conduit for anyone in need of temporary accommodation for pets or other animals. 
We are in touch with local vets, rescue groups, catteries, kennels and others who can help, so we can connect those in need.We have extra staff on to take these calls; anyone who needs help please give us a call on (03) 349 7057. 
In terms of helping behind the cordon, we are working on a case-by-case basis, in conjunction with the Christchurch City Council, to get access and assist where we can." 
9.30am: #chchfires #porthillsfire stay safe to my comrades and other emergency services especially the fire boys in the front line #KiaKahaCHCH pic.twitter.com/IGYoBAFGPf 
9.10am: We're thinking of our #Christchurch whanau. Our Disaster Welfare & Support teams are on standby. Stay safe everyone. — New Zealand RedCross (@NZRedCross) February 15, 2017 
9.07am: In addition to rural fire staff, a group of 86 made up of 50 New Zealand Police and 36 New Zealand Defence Force personnel are working on the Port Hills Fire response. They are doing evacuations, joint patrols and reassuring people in the areas impacted by the fires. 
9.03am: The fire is threatening radio and cell phone transmission towers on the Sugarloaf hill. Kordia says spare transmission equipment is being taken to Christchurch and radio stations say people should switch to the AM frequency if they go off air. 
The blaze, which started as two separate fires on Monday and which sparked a local Civil Defence state of emergency, was fanned by wind change, merged into one and covered more than 1850ha on Wednesday night, Civil Defence says. 
Reports suggest it has now spread to the harbour side of Sugarloaf. 
Sixteen helicopters with monsson buckets took to the air at first light on Thursday but it could be another grim day. 
Rain isn't expected until Friday afternoon. 
"It's not a really good forecast for firefighting... we are expecting winds to develop this afternoon," Civil Defence controller Dave Adamson told RNZ. 
An easterly wind is expected to turn into a northerly over the morning, with wind speeds picking up to 30km/h in the afternoon. 
"At this point in time the fire's not threatening any other properties... but we'll just have to see how the day and the fire develops," Mr Adamson said. 
On Thursday morning, Christchurch Civil Defence said a temperature drop and rise in humidity had helped drop the fire activity. 
"There are still some very active fire fronts up on the Port Hills, but not as many as there were prior to midnight," the council said. 
8.49am: UPDATE: Governors Bay School will be open today. It was closed on Monday and Tuesday, but a staff member told 1 NEWS they have notified parents the school is in full swing today. 
8.44pm: Some more images from the fire: Source: Getty. 
8.37am: This image captures the fire's footprint as of 5.30pm on Wednesday. Source: Christchurch City Council. 
The fire has now spread to over 1850 hectares.
